(subsectors):  Energy

Category  A.  A  summary  environmental  impact  assessment  was 
circulated  to  the  Board  and  posted  on  the  Asian  Development 
Bank (ADB) website on 14 April 2008. 
 
The  Tianjin  Integrated  Gasification  Combined  Cycle  Power  Plant 
Project involves constructing and operating a coal-fired integrated 
gasification  combined  cycle  (IGCC)  power  plant  with  250 
megawatt  capacity  in  Tianjin  Harbor  Industrial  Park  in  the  Binhai 
New  Area  of  Tianjin  city.  This  will  be  the  first  IGCC  clean  coal 
project  in  the  PRC,  using  the  most  efficient  and  least-polluting 
technology currently available commercially. It will also be the first 
IGCC  power  plant  in  the  developing  Asia.  On  completion,  the 
plant  will  generate  1,470  gigawatt-hours  of  electricity  annually, 
which will be sold to the Northern China Grid Company Ltd. using 
a  220  kilovolt  interconnecting  transmission  line  to  an  existing 
substation in the industrial park.  
 
The Project is consistent with the priority of the Government of the 
PRC  to  implement  a  coal-fired  power  plant  with  near-zero 
emissions  by  2015  under  its  flagship  clean  coal  program—
GreenGen—announced  in  2005.  The  Project  is  a  cornerstone  of 
the  critical  first  phase  of  the  GreenGen  program.  In  the  second 
phase,  a  scaled-up  IGCC  plant  fitted  with  pilot-scale  carbon 
capture  and  storage  (CCS)  is  expected  by  2013,  and  the  third 
phase  is  expected  to  provide  a  coal-fired  power  plant  with  near-
zero  emissions  by  2015.  CCS  is  included  in  all  climate  change-
mitigation 
the  United  Nation's 
Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and the International 
Energy  Agency.  Various  international  studies  have  found  IGCC 
power  plants  with  CCS  to  be  the  least-cost  option  to  cut  carbon 
dioxide  (CO2)  emissions  from  coal-fired  power  plants  by  up  to 
90%.  By  successfully  demonstrating  the  advantages  of  IGCC 
technology, the Project will reinforce confidence in the viability of 
this  technology  and  enable  the  timely  implementation  of  the 
ensuing phases of the GreenGen program.  
 
Relevant  approvals  for  the  construction  are  in  place.  Project  
completion  is expected by 30 June 2012.

the 

total  electricity 

The PRC is the world’s largest coal producer and consumer. Coal 
production has increased from 0.98 billion tons (t) in 2000 to 2.74 
billion  t  in  2008,  or  more  than  48%  of  global  production.  In  the 
PRC,  electricity  is  produced  predominantly  from  coal,  which 
in  2008.  Electricity 
generated  81%  of 
generation  is  the  largest  single  consumer  of  coal.  It  consumed 
1.34  billion  t  (49%)  of  the  coal  produced  in  2008,  with  serious 
environmental  problems  and  poor  air  quality  caused  by  related 
emissions—50%  of  the  nation’s  sulfur  dioxide  (SO2)  emissions, 
36%  of  its  nitrogen  oxide  (NOX)  emissions,  and  39%  of  its  CO2 
emissions.  Acid  rain  caused  primarily  by  SO2  and  NOx  falls  on 
one-third  of  the  country  and  45%  of  its  farmland.  The  rapid 
increase  in  coal  consumption  has  triggered  a  surge  in  emissions 
of  CO2—a  major  greenhouse  gas  (GHG)  and  cause  of  global 
climate change.  
 
The  Government  is  actively  improving  energy  efficiency  and 
shifting  to  non-carbon  and  other  cleaner  energy  sources  to 
improve  the  country’s  environment  and  help  mitigate  global 
climate  change.  The  Renewable  Energy  Law,  enacted  in  2006, 
brought unprecedented growth in wind, solar, and biomass power 
generation. Carbon-free nuclear power is expected to grow many 
folds. The PRC already has the largest hydropower capacity in the 
world,  which  is  expected  to  grow  substantially.  Despite  efforts  to 
change  the  energy  mix,  coal  is  expected  to  remain  dominant  in 
electricity production in the near future.  
 
To improve the efficiency of and reduce emissions from coal-fired 
power  plants,  the  PRC  is  (i)  rapidly  closing  small,  inefficient 
plants,  as  indicated  by  the  closing  of  54  gigawatts  of  such 
capacity 
the  past  3  years  alone;  (ii)  constructing  new 
supercritical  and  ultra-supercritical  (USC)  plants  with  advanced 
international 
technology 
standards;  and  (iii)  accelerating  the  application  of  flue  gas  de-
sulfurization.  The  development  of  coal-fired  IGCC  power  plants 
has  been  slow,  though  they  can  offer  4%–5%  higher  efficiency 
than  USC  plants.  So  far,  no  industrial-scale  IGCC  plant  is 
the  PRC.  Higher  capital  and,  operation  and 
operating 
maintenance  (O&M)  costs  (affecting  electricity 
tariffs),  and 
technology  risks  are  cited  as  key  barriers.  IGCC  technology  is, 
however, gaining momentum in part because of the opportunity of 
combining it with CCS to cut emissions drastically.  
 
The  Project  will  demonstrate  a  key  enabling  technology  with 
potential  for  large  GHG  emission  reductions  from  coal  usage  in 
the  largest  coal-consuming  country  in  the  world.  ADB  project 
support  will  provide  additional  technical  due  diligence  and  help 
mitigate  associated  risks,  strengthen  compliance  with  safeguard 
policies,  and  thereby  establish  appropriate  benchmarks  and 
standards

The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $419.59 million, 
inclusive of physical and price contingencies ($22.50 million) and 
financial charges during development ($22.10 million).  
 
A  loan  of  $135  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  will 
be provided under ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility. The loan will have a 26-year term, including 
a grace period of 6 years. The long grace period of 6 years, when 
compared with a 3-year construction period, is proposed as part of 
the 
this  project  demonstrating  new 
technology  during  its  initial  years  of  operation.  The  loan  will  be 
subject  to  interest  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  the  applicable  commitment  charge, 
and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  set  forth  in  the  loan  and 
project  agreements.  ADB  provides  flexibility  in  terms  of  currency 
and interest rate swaps during the financing period, in accordance 
with relevant loan regulations and loan and project agreements.  
 
ADB's  Climate  Change  Fund  (CCF)  will  provide  a  grant  of  $5 
million to finance some key components to mitigate risk.  
 
The Borrower of ADB loan will be the PRC. Loan proceeds will be 
relent  by  the  Borrower  through  the  Ministry  of  Finance  to  the 
Export-Import Bank of China (EXIM Bank) on the same terms and 
conditions  as  the  loan  between  ADB  and  the  PRC.  EXIM  Bank 
will, in turn, onlend these loan proceeds to China Huaneng Group 
(CHNG)  on  similar  loan  terms  as  the  EXIM  Bank  loan  and 
additionally  include  a  standard  administration  fee  of  0.15%  for 
providing these onlending services. CHNG, through an onlending 
agreement,  will  then  onlend  the  loan  proceeds  to  the  Greengen 
Company  Ltd  (Greengen),  who  in  turn  will  onlend  it  to  Huaneng 
Tianjin IGCC Company Ltd. (HTICL) as the implementing agency 
(IA)  under  a  subsequent  onlending  agreement,  which  again  will 
incorporate the same terms and conditions as CHNG's agreement 
with EXIM Bank. HTICL shall bear the risk of currency and interest 
rate fluctuation.

entity,  Greengen  management 

The  EXIM  Bank  acts  as  the  principal  onlending  agency.  CHNG 
will be the Executing Agency (EA). CHNG is the managing partner 
of  Greengen,  which  established  the  project  company  HTICL  in 
Tianjin  for  the  construction,  operation,  and  maintenance  of  the 
power  plant.  HTICL  was  registered  as  a  limited  liability  company 
under  PRC  law  in  November  2008.  While  HTICL  is  a  separate 
legal 
provides 
management  oversight  to  HTICL.  A  project  implementation  unit 
(PIU)  established  in  HTICL  will  regularly  monitor  implementation 
progress.  The  PIU  will  be  headed  by  a  project  manager 
responsible for day to day implementation and the preparation of 
progress  reports.  The  PIU  will  be  assisted  by  a  team  of 
international and national consultants to enhance its capacity with 
regard  to  safeguard  compliance  and  for  project  management, 
monitoring, and reporting.  
 
China Huaneng Group  
 
Project procurement will be carried out in accordance with ADB's 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Advance contracting for the Project was approved in August 2008. 
CHNG  and  HTICL  have  requested  retroactive  financing  for  the 
procurement  of  goods,  works,  and  consulting  services.  The 
amount  to  be  retroactively  financed  will  not  exceed  20%  of  the 
loan  amount  and  will  be  effective  for  reasonable  expenditures 
incurred before loan effectiveness but not earlier than 12 months 
before the signing date of the loan agreement. 
 
Consulting  services  for  16  person-months—4  international  and  
12  national—will  be  provided  to  assist  HTICL  with  the  Project's 
implementation, especially regarding compliance with safeguards, 
and 
in  project  management,  monitoring,  and  reporting.  All 
consultants  will  be  selected  and  engaged  in  accordance  with 
ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as  amended 
from time to time). 
 
The  Project  is  financially  viable  and  economically  attractive.  The 
financial  internal  rate  of  return  is  6.4%,  which  is  higher  than  the 
weighted  average  cost  of  capital  of  3.7%.  The  economic  internal 
rate  of  return  is  16.5%,  higher  than  the  ADB  minimum  rate  of 
12%. Sensitivity tests and risk analysis show that the Project will 
be  economically  and  financially  viable  even  under  a  combination 
of adverse scenarios. Potential carbon offset revenues under the 
Clean  Development  Mechanism  will  further  improve  the  financial 
and economic benefits from the Project. 
 
The  Project  will  demonstrate  an  innovative  and  advanced  clean 
coal  IGCC  technology  that  will  be  tested  for  the  first  time  in  the 
PRC. The Project will have significant environmental benefits with 
reduced emissions of major air pollutants like SO2, NOx, and total 
suspended  particulates  (TSP) as  compared with a  conventional 

 v 

power  plant.  The  estimated  annual  emissions  avoided  by  the 
Project are 43 t of TSP, 1,237 t of SO2, and 3,325 t of NOx. The 
Project will reduce annual coal consumption by 134,000 t and CO2 
emissions  by  372,000  t,  with  associated  global  climate  benefits. 
The  Project  is  expected  to  use  35%  less  cooling  water  and 
generate significantly less solid waste than a conventional plant.    
 
The Project has acquired 20 hectares of land reclaimed from the 
Bohai  Sea  in  an  existing  industrial  park  and  therefore  does  not 
entail  any  resettlement.  Based  on  ADB's  safeguard  policies,  it  is 
category  C  in  terms  of  involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous 
people  impacts.  The  Project  will  provide  indirect  social  benefits 
through  improved  air  quality  in  the  project  area.  During  project 
construction, the peak number of workers may reach 1,000.  
 
Project  implementation  carries  risks  inherent  in  any  project 
demonstrating  an  advanced  technology  for  the  first  time  in  a  
country. While all the major components of the Project have been 
pilot  tested  or  established  commercially  and  are  in  successful 
operation  in  the  PRC,  these  components  have  not  yet  been 
combined  in  a  reliable  industrial-sized  IGCC  power  plant.  This 
first-of-a-kind  risk  exists  in  this  demonstration  project,  especially 
during  the  first  2  years  of  operation.  The  risk  is  substantially 
reduced  with  the  help  of  a  $5  million  grant  from  ADB's  CCF  that 
will  sponsor  the  assistance  of  the  coal  gasifier  and  gas  turbine 
suppliers  in  O&M  for  the  initial  2  years.  The  suppliers'  direct 
supervision  and  support  during  this  critical  phase,  financed 
through the grant, will (i) provide enhanced technical expertise at 
short  notice;  (ii)  help  quickly  diagnose  problems;  and  (iii) 
strengthen the quality of O&M, which will help the Project quickly 
stabilize at its designed performance level. 
 
The  major  change  in  an  IGCC  power  plant  compared  with  a 
conventional  plant  is  the  introduction  of  coal  gasification.  Coal 
gasification  is  a  mature  technology  widely  used  in  chemical 
industries  in  the  PRC.  The  Project  will  use  a  domestically 
developed  coal  gasifier,  which  is  a  scaled-up  version  of  a 
prototype  that  was  extensively  tested  on  the  same  coal  type.  To 
further mitigate risks associated with the reliability of the installed 
coal  gasifier,  the  Project  will  have  interconnection  with  two 
similarly  sized  imported  coal  gasifiers  that  are  installed  in  a 
chemical  factory  next  to  the  project  site.  This  connection  will 
provide  backup  in  case  the  gasifier  breaks  down,  thus  ensuring 
the reliability of electricity supply from the Project.  
 
Project  implementation  risks  are  minimal.  It  will  be  implemented 
by a very experienced and capable group of large power and coal 
companies,  with  strong  support  from  the  Government.  The  EA, 
design  institutes,  and  key  suppliers  have  extensive  experience 
and  expertise  in  designing,   constructing,  and  managing  large 

 
Risks and Assumptions 

 

 

 vi 

 

 

 
Grant Assistance  

coal-fired  power  plants.  CHNG,  Greengen  and  HTICL  have 
undertaken  an  extensive  recruitment  and  training  program  for 
engineers and operators with chemical engineering background to 
complement its extensive thermal power plant expertise. Key staff 
has  been  trained  on  the  O&M  of  a  similar  IGCC  power  plant  in 
Spain.  The  trained  staff  will  improve  the  sustainability  of  the 
Project and minimize risks. 
 
Electricity tariffs in the PRC are regulated and set nationally by the 
National  Development  and  Reform  Commission  (NDRC).  As  this 
is  the  first  IGCC  power  plant,  the  cost  estimates  and  proposed 
tariff  were  rigorously  reviewed  during  NDRC’s  approval  of  the 
feasibility  report.  The  Project  is  financially  viable  at  the  tariff  of 
CNY0.56/kilowatt-hour  proposed  in  the  feasibility  report.  The 
electricity tariff for the Project will be announced by NDRC only at 
project  completion.  Since  NDRC  has  already  reviewed  and 
approved  the  feasibility  report,  the  risk  of  any  tariff  lower  than  in 
the feasibility report is minimal.   
 
Grant  assistance  is  proposed  from  CCF  not  exceeding  the 
equivalent  of  $5  million.  The  grant  will  be  utilized  for  the  (i)  coal 
gasifier’s and gas turbines’ long-term maintenance contracts with 
their  respective  suppliers,  (ii)  civil  work  contract  associated  with 
the  air  separation  unit  of  the  chemical  island  plants,  and  (iii) 
recruitment  of  international  and  national  consultants  to  supervise 
the  Project's 
implementation.  The  grant  assistance  will 
significantly  reduce  risks  and  strengthen  project  management 
capacity and reporting on compliance with key safeguards. 

 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan, and (ii) a proposed grant to be provided  by ADB's Climate Change Fund (CCF), both to 
the  People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Tianjin  Integrated  Gasification  Combined  Cycle 
(IGCC) Power Plant Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

 
Performance Indicators and Analysis   

A. 

2. 
The  PRC  has  sustained  impressive  economic  growth  averaging  9.5%  for  the  past  2 
decades. Compared with 2000, its gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to double by 2010 
and  quadruple  by  2020.  The  PRC's  energy  consumption  increased  to  2.85  billion  tons  (t)  of 
standard  coal  equivalent  by  end-2008,  about  20%  of  global  energy  consumption  and  121% 
higher  than  the  1.29  billion  t  of  standard  coal  equivalent  consumed  in  2000. 1  Given  the 
projected  growth  trajectory  and  relatively  low  per  capita  energy  consumption  of  0.72  t  of  oil 
equivalent (toe) per annum, the PRC's demand for energy is expected to increase rapidly. Coal 
is the dominant source of primary energy, contributing 70% in 2008, which is significantly higher 
than the world average of 26%.2  
 
The  PRC  is  the  world’s  largest  coal  producer  and  consumer,  as  well  as  a  net  energy 
3. 
importer,  mainly  of  oil  and  gas.  In  2008,  crude  oil  imports  were  more  than  178  million  t.  The 
PRC's  reliance  on  imported  oil  has  now  increased  to  more  than  50%  of  total  oil consumption. 
The  consistently  increasing  demand  for  energy  has  impacted  upon  energy  security  and  may 
become a barrier to sustained economic growth.3 A key priority in the 11th Five-Year Plan (FYP) 
2006–2010 is to lower energy intensity by 20%.4 At the end of 2008, energy intensity had fallen 
by  9%  compared  with  2005.5 By  international  standards,  energy  intensity  in  the  PRC  is  still 
relatively high at about 0.92 toe, compared with 0.21 toe for the United States and 0.15 toe for 
Japan.  
 
4. 
The rapid pace of economic growth has created strong demand for electricity. Per capita 
electricity consumption increased from 993 kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 2000 to 2,650 kWh in 2008.6 
After  the  United  States,  the  PRC  has  the  second-largest  electricity  industry  in  the  world.  Both 
installed  generation  capacity  and  actual  electricity  generation  increased  at  an  annual  average 
rate of more than 8% over the past 2 decades. Since 2001, electricity demand has increased at 
an  average  rate  of  more  than  13%.  This  increase  caused  serious  power  shortages  in  many 
areas of the PRC, which were overcome with an accelerated program of adding more capacity. 
Total installed capacity has now reached 792.5 gigawatts (GW), and electricity generation has 
increased  to  3,433  terawatt-hours  (TWh).  The  current  growth  trajectory  has  installed  capacity 
reaching more than 1,000 GW by 2012.

5. 
In  the  PRC,  electricity  is  produced  predominantly  by  coal,  which  is  the  most  carbon-
intensive  fossil  fuel.7 In  2008,  coal-fired  power  plants  produced  81%  of  total  electricity.  Coal 
production increased from 0.98 billion t in 2000 to 2.74 billion t in 2008, more than 48% of world 
production.  The  electricity  sector  is  the  largest  consumer  of  coal.  It  consumed  1.34  billion  t 
(49%)  of  the  coal  produced  in  2008,  which  has  caused  serious  environmental  problems.  Coal 
consumption is the major cause of poor air quality. The electricity sector now produces 50% of 
the nation’s sulfur dioxide (SO2) emissions, 36% of its nitrogen oxide (NOX) emissions, and 39% 
of its carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions. Acid rain caused primarily by SO2 and NOx falls on one 
third of the country and 45% of its farmland. In 2008, among 519 PRC cities with monitored air 
quality, only 399 met acceptable air quality (national class II) standards. The rapid increase in 
coal consumption has triggered a surge in emissions of CO2—a major greenhouse gas (GHG).8 
As per the International Energy Agency (IEA) World Energy Outlook 20099 the PRC is expected 
to add more than 1,000 GW of new capacity by 2030, of which 70% will be coal-fired. Most of 
this new capacity is expected before 2020.  
 
6. 
A  more  diversified  energy  mix  with  a  higher  proportion  of  carbon-free  renewable 
sources,  nuclear  power,  and  low-carbon  fossil  fuel  such  as  natural  gas  is  being  actively 
pursued.  The  Renewable  Energy  Law,  enacted  in  2006,  provides  financial  incentives  and 
regulations to accelerate the increased use of renewable energy resources such as wind, solar 
energy, and biomass. This led to unprecedented growth in wind power capacity within the first 3 
years  (2006–2008)  of  the  11th  FYP.  The  PRC  now  has  12  GW  of  wind  power  capacity, 
compared  with  less  than  1  GW  at  end-2005.  Solar  power  development  is  expected  to  reach      
2  GW  by  2011.  The  11th  FYP  also  targets  5.5  GW  of  biomass  power  development.  The 
Government  of  the  PRC  has  set  the  goal  to  achieve  15%  of  electricity  generation  from 
renewable energy sources by 2020 in its renewable energy development plans, promulgated in 
August 2007. The current growth momentum of renewable energy is expected to continue and 
may achieve an even higher target.  
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Key Problems and Constraints 

The  PRC  quadrupled  its  GDP  during  1980–2000,  but  its  energy  consumption  only 
7. 
doubled. The average energy elasticity of the GDP10 was 0.47. Since 2002, it increased sharply, 
peaking at about 1.6 in 2004, and declined to 0.7 in 2007. The consistently high average energy 
elasticity  of  GDP  of  about  0.95  during  2001–2007  has  led,  however,  to  large  energy  imports 
(para.  3)  with  repercussions  for  energy  security.  To  achieve  the  target  of  quadrupling  the 
economy  while only doubling energy use between  2000 and 2020, energy elasticity has to be 
brought down and maintained at below 0.3 over the next 12 years—a very formidable challenge. 
Tighter  regulations  and  the  right  incentives  are  required  to  further  lower  energy  intensity. 
Investment in energy efficiency needs to increase substantially to achieve this target.11  
 
8. 
The  surge  in  new  generation  capacity  to  meet  the  growing  demand  for  electricity 
materialized  in  260  GW  of  new  power  plant  capacity  in  the  3-year  period  2006–2008,  an

9. 
plants is a key priority for lowering emissions and improving energy security. A high percentage 
of  new  coal-fired  power-generating  units  are—large  from  300  megawatts  (MW)  up  to  1  GW—
with  supercritical  and  ultra-supercritical  (USC) 
that  provide  much  higher 
efficiency.13 During 2006–2008, about 54 GW of old and inefficient coal-fired generators smaller 
than  100  MW  were  closed,  and  the  average  efficiency  of  coal-fired  power  plants  improved  to 
340  grams  of  standard  coal/kWh  from  370  grams/kWh,  avoiding  160  million  t  of  coal  usage 
during this period. In general, the new USC plants have efficiencies on a par with or higher than 
international  standards,  but  average  plant  efficiencies  in  the  PRC  are  still  much  lower  than 
international  standards  because  of  the  country’s  many  old  and  inefficient  power  plants.  With 
more  supercritical  and  USC  plants,  average  efficiency  will  gradually  improve.  It  is  still  unlikely 
that coal consumption or emissions will drop, as many new coal-fired power plants will continue 
to  come  online.  A  technology  change  is  therefore  essential  in  coal-fired  power  plants  to 
decouple high coal usage from CO2 emissions.      
 
The  internationally  available  and  more  advanced  clean  coal  technologies 14  such  as 
10. 
IGCC,  which  potentially  offer  even  higher  efficiency  and  far  superior  emission  performances 
than  advanced  supercritical  and  USC  plants,  are  not  currently  installed  in  the  PRC.  IGCC 
technology  turns  coal  into  synthesis  gas  (syngas).  It  then  removes  impurities  from  the  syngas 
before it is combusted. This reduces emissions of SO2 and NOx by almost 99%. It also brings 
4%–5% higher efficiency compared with supercritical plants.15 The higher costs of IGCC plants 
and  perceived  technology  risks  from  complex  design  have  been  major  barriers  to  its  larger 
uptake.16 On  their  own,  IGCC  power  plants  offer  only  limited  CO2  emission  reductions  from 
higher  efficiency.  But  the  emergence  of  technology  to  separate,  capture,  transport,  and  store 
CO2—generally referred to as CO2 capture and storage (CCS)—has provided renewed impetus 
for  the  rapid  adoption  of  IGCC  technologies.17 Various  international  studies  have  found  IGCC 
power plants with CCS to be the least-cost option to cut CO2 emissions from coal-fired power

11. 
CCS  involves  capturing  CO2  from  coal-fired  power  plants  either  before  combustion 
(IGCC plants) or after combustion (supercritical or USC plants) and long-term storage in deep 
geological  formations  such  as  depleted  oil  and  gas  wells.  According  to  an  IEA  assessment, 
CCS presents the most promising GHG mitigation for coal-fired electricity generation.19 It is part 
of all climate change-mitigation strategies considered by IEA and the Intergovernmental Panel 
on  Climate  Change  (IPCC).  To  date,  there  is  no  industrial-scale  coal-fired  power  plant  with 
CCS.  However,  CCS  has  been  used  successfully  in  the  oil  and  gas  industry  for  many  years. 
CCS  is  particularly  relevant  for  a  large  coal-based  economy  like  PRC  to  decouple  its  growing 
energy  needs  from  rising  CO2  emissions,  a  critical  factor  to  lower  the  carbon  intensity  of  the 
economy.20  
 

2. 

Opportunities  

 
12. 
To  recognize  the  central  role  of  coal  in  long-term  energy  security,  and  to  ensure  the 
environmental sustainability of rapidly increasing coal-fired generation capacity, the Government 
announced the GreenGen program in October 2005. Greengen Company Ltd (Greengen) was 
launched  in  December  2005  with  a  mandate  to  lead  the  research,  development,  and 
demonstration  (RD&D)  of  IGCC  and  CCS  technologies,  leading  to  a  near-zero  emission  coal-
fired  power  plant  by  2015  under  the  GreenGen  program.  China  Huaneng  Group  (CHNG),  the 
largest electricity-generating company in the PRC, is the managing company of Greengen, with 
51% of shares.21 Greengen has drawn up a three-phase RD&D program. The first phase (2008–
2011)  aims  to  implement  the  250  MW  Tianjin  IGCC  plant  (the  Project).22 The  second  phase 
(2011–2013) is expected to implement a scaled-up IGCC plant of 400 MW and more with pilot 
testing of CCS. The third phase (2015 onwards) will implement fully integrated IGCC and CCS 
with  a  near-zero  emission  coal-fired  power  plant.  The  Project  is  supported  by  the  Ministry  of 
Science  and  Technology  (MOST)  and  the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission 
(NDRC). It is listed as one of the major projects for scientific development in the 11th FYP under 
the  National  High-Tech  RD&D  Program.  Tianjin  is  selected  as  the  location  in  consideration  of 
future CCS application and its proximity (45 kilometers) to the Dagang oil field, which is owned 
by  China  National  Petroleum  Corporation. 23  Appendix  2  includes  more  information  on  the 
GreenGen program.  
 
13. 
CHNG is a wholly state-owned enterprise (SOE) that has been at the forefront of clean 
coal  technologies  and  led  supercritical  and  USC  development  and  deployment  in  the  PRC.  It 
doubled  its  installed  capacity  of  43  GW  in  2005  to  86  GW  in  2008  and  contributes  10%  to 
national  electricity  production,  generating  364.5  TWh  in  2008.  CHNG  has,  as  the  managing 
company  of  Greengen,  identified  the  project  location  as  its  IGCC  base.  It  is  expected  to 
consider installing more than 1 GW of IGCC capacity by 2015. CHNG also implemented a 3,000 
t/year pilot project of CO2 capture and industrial utilization in 2008 at its Gao Bei Dian plant, a

technology  and  identify  a  clear  pathway  for  multiple  demonstration  projects  and  its  future  full-

3. 

Strategies of the Government  

jointly  owned  provincial  power-generation  companies,  along  with 

 
15. 
The  Government  has  implemented  significant  reforms  in  the  energy  sector.  National 
energy enterprises have autonomy for investment decisions, and coal prices are gradually being 
deregulated. The power subsector was unbundled in 2003 with the creation of five national and 
two  power-
several 
transmission  and  distribution  companies  that  have  provincial  subsidiaries  for  satisfying 
consumer demand. However, transmission and distribution functions are still bundled together. 
Unbundling  these  functions  is  being  carefully  considered.  The  independent  State  Electricity 
Regulatory Commission is now present in all provinces. Recognizing the importance of energy 
to the national economy, the National Energy Administration was set up within NDRC in 2008 
and is now functional. NDRC regulates the retail electricity tariff. The adoption and approval of 
new  technology  and  demonstration  plants  are  carefully  considered  before  approval  of 
investment  decisions.  The  approach  is  to  encourage  competition  and  send  a  strong  signal 
regarding efficiency even at the demonstration stage. This approach, combined with the largest 
market  for  new  and  innovative  technologies,  proved  successful  in  bringing  down  costs,  thus 
facilitating quick deployment, as demonstrated in the large addition of new wind power projects 
in  the  past  3  years.  Tariff-setting  principles  are  based  on  cost  recovery  with  adequate  returns 
and have been consistently applied for more than a decade. Higher tariffs for new technology 
projects have been consistently approved. Appendix 3 provides more details on the sector.  
 
The Government recognizes the environmental challenges and climate change impacts 
16. 
of its growing energy use and prioritized energy efficiency and environmental protection in the 
11th FYP. The plan includes obligatory targets to improve energy intensity by 20% and reduce 
by  10%  major  pollutants,  including  SO2,  which  is  emitted  mostly  by  coal-fired  power  plants. 
Since  the  announcement  of  the  targets,  the  State  Council  has  issued  a  number  of  guidelines 
and  plans  to  intensify  efforts  to  improve  energy  efficiency  and  reduce  pollution.  The  recently 
amended Energy Conservation Law became effective on 1 April 2008. Power generation plays 
a  significant  role  in  energy  efficiency  improvement  and  has  shown  consistent  progress  in 
improving  the  efficiency  of  coal-fired  power  plants  and  lowering  emissions.  The  Government 
announced  in  2008  its  Climate  Change  Action  Plan,  which  recognizes  the  importance  of 
scientific research and supports developing advanced technologies such as IGCC and CCS. In

4. 

Strategies of the Asian Development Bank 

 
ADB  energy  sector  strategies  are  fully  aligned  with  the  Government’s  11th  FYP 
17. 
strategies and plans. ADB supports the Government’s sector strategies to move towards a low-
carbon path through (i) energy efficiency and conservation, (ii) renewable energy development, 
(iii) urban environment improvement through more efficient energy production and distribution, 
(iv) clean coal technology development, (v) coal mine and coal bed methane development, and 
(vi)  regional  cooperation  to  strengthen  energy  security.  Clean  coal  development  has  been  a 
priority  area  for  ADB  operations  in  the  PRC.  ADB  provided  grant-financed  TA25 in  1997  to 
assess  the  appropriateness  of  IGCC  technologies  and  prepare  the  conceptual  design  of  an 
IGCC  demonstration  plan.26 The  TA  was  implemented  in  close  cooperation  with  the  Thermal 
Power  Research  Institute  (TPRI)  in  Xian,  the  leading  research  organization  in  thermal  power 
engineering in the PRC.27 Since late 2007, ADB has worked closely with CHNG and Greengen 
and  provided  a  small-scale  TA  in  2008  to  support  project  development.28 Recognizing  the  key 
role of IGCC and CCS technologies in climate change mitigation, ADB has formed partnerships 
with  leading  knowledge  bodies—the  Carbon  Sequestration  Leadership  Forum  and  the  Global 
CCS  Institute  in  Australia—in  this  emerging  area  directly  relevant  to  its  developing  member 
countries. These partnerships have provided access to expert networks and created dedicated 
resources to help accelerate CCS demonstration.29  
 
18. 
ADB’s Clean Energy and Environment Program includes innovative instruments such as 
the multidonor-funded, $150 million Asia Pacific Carbon Fund, Future Carbon Fund, and CCF. 
All  these  funds  are  directly  relevant  to  the  Project’s  need  for  low-cost,  long-term  financing 
aiming to demonstrate an innovative technology. By successfully demonstrating the advantages 
of  IGCC  technology  the  Project  will  reinforce  confidence  in  the  viability  of  this  technology  and 
encourage policy makers to approve more IGCC projects. Multiple demonstration projects with 
international support will shorten the learning curve and help achieve economies of scale. ADB 
project support will provide additional technical due diligence and help mitigate risks, strengthen 
compliance with  safeguards,  and  thereby  establish  appropriate  benchmarks  and standards  for 
future IGCC projects.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

Outputs 

Impact and Outcome 

 
A. 
 
21. 
The impact of the Project will be reduced GHG emissions from coal-fired power plants. 
The  outcome  will  be  the  IGCC  plants  demonstrating  climate  change  mitigation  effect  of  new 
technology deployed. 
 
B. 
 
22. 
The  project outputs  include  (i)  constructing  and  operating  an  IGCC  power  plant  of  250 
MW capacity in Binhai New Area, Tianjin city for generating 1,470 gigawatt-hours of electricity 
annually, which will be sold to the Northern China Grid Company Limited through a 220 kilovolt 
interconnecting  transmission  line;  (ii)  adequate  capacity  in  project  management,  safeguard 
compliance,  and  plant  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M);  and  (iii)  capacity  developed  for

C. 
 

Special Features 

1. 

Demonstration of an Innovative and Advanced Clean Coal Technology  

 
The  Project  will  introduce  IGCC  technology,  the  most  efficient  and  least  polluting 
23. 
advanced clean coal technology currently available commercially (para. 10, footnotes 15) for the 
first time in PRC. Technologically, the Project represents a significant change from conventional 
coal-fired  power  plants  as  it  involves  the  gasification  of  the  coal  before  combustion.  As  a 
collaborative project of all major energy enterprises in the PRC (para. 12 and footnote 21), the 
Project offers a natural knowledge platform and will disseminate experiences and results to all 
major energy enterprises in the PRC. The Project is a cornerstone of the critical first of the three 
phases  in  the  GreenGen  program  (para.  12)  that  is  expected  to  lead  to  a  near-zero  emission 
coal-fired  power  plant  by  2015.  Project  implementation  will  provide  valuable  insights  into  the 
challenges,  issues,  and  benefits  of  IGCC  technologies  that  will  guide  the  ensuing  phases.  By 
successfully  applying  IGCC  technology  in  an  industrial-size  coal-fired  power  plant,  the  Project 
will  bolster  the  confidence  of  investors,  project  developers,  and  policy  makers  in  IGCC 

 

 8 

 

technology  and  pave  the  way  for  multiple  demonstration  projects.  As  more  IGCC  plants  are 
implemented  and  designers  get  more  confident  in  dealing  with  the  technology,  larger  IGCC 
plants in the range of 400 MW and higher will be implemented, which will reduce costs per MW 
and  narrow  the  current  incremental  cost  gap  of  80%  compared  with  USC  plants  to  20%.  The 
PRC  is  potentially  the  largest  market  for  IGCC,  whose  wider  deployment  will  encourage  cost-
competitive local manufacturing of key components, which will further reduce the cost and bring 
rapid deployment.  
 

2. 

Innovative Risk Mitigation Measures 

 
24. 
Project implementation carries risks inherent in any project demonstrating an advanced 
and  innovative  technology  for  the  first  time  in  a  country.  A  unique  approach  was  adopted  to 
substantially  reduce  risk  without  increasing  project  cost,  which  is  already  a  major  barrier  to 
promoting IGCC technology. Lessons on improving the sustainability and performance of similar 
IGCC power plants in Europe and elsewhere were incorporated into project design by utilizing 
part  of  the  $5  million  grant  from  ADB's  CCF.30 The  initial  O&M  period  of  about  2  years  for  an 
IGCC  demonstration  plant  is  critical  to  ensuring  its  sustainability,  especially  for  its  key 
components—the coal gasifier and gas turbines. The suppliers' direct supervision and support 
during  this  critical  phase,  financed  through  the  grant,  will  (i)  provide  enhanced  technical 
expertise at a short notice; (ii) help quickly diagnose problems; and (iii) strengthen the quality of 
O&M,  which  will  help  the  Project  quickly  stabilize  at  its  designed  performance  level.  Supplier-
assisted O&M will provide on-the-job training to HTICL staff, thereby developing their capacity 
and  enhancing  the  sustainability  of  the  Project.  The  grant  will  also  be  used  to  engage 
international and national consultants for a total of 16 person-months to support the compliance 
with  the  safeguards,  and  in  project  management,  monitoring  and  reporting.  This  will  establish 
appropriate  benchmarks  and  standards  for  future  IGCC  projects.  Additionally,  to  avoid  any 
financial distress to HTICL during the initial operation period, a grace period of 6 years for the 
ADB loan is included.  
 

Potential Benefits from Clean Development Mechanism 

3. 
 
The  Project  is  anticipated  to  be  eligible  for  certified  emission  reductions  (CERs)  under 
25. 
the  Clean  Development  Mechanism  (CDM). 31  By  applying  the  approved  Consolidated 
Methodology, 32  emission  reductions  will  be  achieved  through  higher  efficiency,  thereby 
replacing coal usage in pulverized coal-fired power generation. Based on this methodology, four 
high-efficiency pulverized coal-fired power plants in the PRC have been designed and are being 
prepared for the CDM validation stage. The Project will construct the first IGCC power plant in 
the PRC that would be eligible under the modalities and procedures of CDM. ADB's Technical 
Support  Facility  under  its  Carbon  Market  Initiative  (CMI)  is  helping  Greengen  to  develop  the 
CDM  project  design  document  based  on  the  approved  methodology  to  support  its  registration 
with  the  CDM  Executive  Board.  As  IGCC  technology  is  considered  to  have  high  potential  for 
reducing GHGs, the Technical Support Facility’s additional support for devices and processes to 
monitor  and  validate  GHG  reduction  is  being  considered  to  provide  enhanced  support  for  this

F. 
 

Implementation Arrangements 

Onlending Arrangements  

1. 
 
30. 
The Borrower of the ADB loan will be the PRC, and loan proceeds will be relent by the 
Borrower through the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to the Export and Import Bank of China (EXIM 
Bank) on the same terms and conditions as the loan between ADB and the PRC. EXIM Bank 
will, in turn, onlend these loan proceeds to CHNG on similar loan terms as the EXIM Bank loan 
and  include  an  administration  fee  of  0.15%  for  providing  onlending  services  to  MOF.  CHNG, 
through an onlending agreement, will then onlend the loan proceeds to Greengen, who will then 
through a separate onlending agreement lend the proceeds to HTICL as the IA under a fourth 
onlending  agreement,  which  again  will  incorporate  the  same  terms  and  conditions  as  their 
agreement with EXIM Bank. HTICL shall bear the risk of currency and interest rate fluctuation. 
Though  HTICL  is  a  separate  legal entity,  it  will  continue  to  have  close  management  links  with 
Greengen, which will provide management oversight to HTICL. Information about EXIM Bank is 
in Appendix 6.   
 
31. 
The  role  of  EXIM  Bank  in  the  Project  is  crucial  to  facilitate  onlending  from  MOF  to 
CHNG, an SOE. EXIM Bank is a policy bank of the Government under the direct administration 

  

11

of  the  State  Council.  It  has  the  same  credit  rating  as  the  Government  of  the  PRC.  Onlending 
loans and grants to SOEs from international financial institutions is one of its main roles. It has 
played a similar role in World Bank and European Investment Bank loans but not yet for ADB 
loans.34 This  onlending  modality  through  EXIM  Bank  will  test  an  innovative  new  approach  for 
future  ADB  lending  support  to  similar  advanced  technology  projects  in  areas  of  clean  energy 
and  climate  change  mitigation  that  will  be  implemented  by  SOEs.  The  fund  flow  of  loan 
proceeds is consistent with the project organization chart included in Appendix 7.    
 

2. 

Project Management 

 
32. 
CHNG will be the EA. It is the managing partner of Greengen, which was established in 
2005 with an authorized share capital of CNY300 million. Greengen established HTICL with the 
mandate  to  develop  the  Project  and  to  be  the  IA.  HTICL  was  registered  as  a  limited  liability 
company under PRC law in November 2008. Greengen will provide management support and 
oversight  to  HTICL,  supporting  Project  implementation,  particularly  in  relation  to  financial 
management, financial control, and accounting, and ensuring good governance of the Project. 
Greengen is also responsible for liaising with CHNG. Establishing HTICL as a separate project 
entity  is  considered  prudent  as  it  (i)  brings  transparency,  (ii)  improves  accountability  and 
corporate  governance,  and  (iii)  ensures  a  task  force  approach  to  project  development  that 
ensures  a  strong  management  focus.  A  project  director  reporting  directly  to  the  president  of 
Greengen  will  be  responsible  for  project  management,  contract  approval,  and  payments.  A 
project  implementation  unit  (PIU)  established  in  HTICL  will  regularly  monitor  and  review 
implementation  progress.  HTICL  has  already  established  an  environmental  management  unit 
(EMU)  to  coordinate  implementation  of  the  environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  with 
contractors and the Tianjin environment protection bureau. The EMU will oversee environmental 
management  and  monitoring  during  construction  and  operation,  including  the  environmental 
supervision  of  contractors.  The  PIU  will  be  headed  by  a  project  manager  responsible  for 
physical  implementation  day  to  day  and  the  preparation  of  progress  reports.  A  team  of 
international  and  national  consultants  will  assist  the  PIU  to  comply  with  safeguards,  and  for 
project monitoring, review, and reporting. An organization chart for implementing the Project is 
in Appendix 7.  
 

3. 

Implementation Period 

 
33. 
The  Project  will  be  implemented  over  3  years  from  2009  to  2012.  The  Project's 
preconstruction activities, such as detailed design, preparing bidding documents, tendering, and 
awarding contracts, began in mid-2008. On-site preconstruction started in July 2009. Main civil 
works will start in February 2010 and take about 20 months. The construction of the Project and 
the expected completion date for the loan is June 2012, however the grant will be implemented 
over a longer period until June 2015 as it involves service contracts during implementation. The 
implementation schedule is in Appendix 8.

IV. 

GRANT FROM THE CLIMATE CHANGE FUND  

 
44. 
Because the Project demonstrates key energy efficiency technology with strong potential 
for climate change mitigation, grant assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $5 million from 
the CCF is proposed. The grant will be utilized for (i) long-term maintenance contracts with the 
suppliers  of  the  coal  gasifier  and  gas  turbines,  (ii)  the  civil  works  contract  cost  for  the  air 
separation unit of the chemical island, and (iii) recruiting international and national consultants 
to  supervise  project  implementation.  The  grant  assistance  will  significantly  reduce  risks  (para. 
24)  and  strengthen  project  management  capacity  and  reporting  on  compliance  with  key 
safeguards.  The  grant  passes  through  the  Borrower  to  HTICL  through  CHNG  and  Greengen. 
The grant utilization plan is in Appendix 10.  
 

V. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

Financial Analysis  

 
A. 
 
The  Project's  financial  viability  is  based  on  an  electricity  tariff  of  CNY0.56/kWh,  as 
45. 
proposed in the feasibility report, which is substantially higher than the prevalent CNY0.38/kWh 
electricity  tariff  from  conventional  coal-fired  power  plants  in  Tianjin.  This  higher  tariff  reflects 
higher capital and O&M costs for the first IGCC power plant in the PRC. While the actual tariff 
will be formally set only after construction is completed, it is anticipated to be about the same as 
the feasibility report tariff.  
 
46. 
The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) and financial net present value (FNPV) were 
calculated for the Project. Potential carbon offset revenues were not included in the base case 
calculation.  The  FIRR  is  6.4%,  which  is  higher  than  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital 
(WACC),  estimated  at  3.7%.  The  FNPV  is  CNY820.9  million  at  this  WACC.  The  Project  is 
considered  financially  viable.  Sensitivity  analysis  shows  that  the  FIRR  is  robust  under  various 

  

15

Financial Performance of Greengen and CHNG  

adverse conditions. The sensitivity analysis showed that the FIRR of the Project would decrease 
to  (i)  6.0%  if  the  Project  experienced  a  cost  overrun  of  10%,  (ii)  4.4%  if  project  benefits  were 
reduced by 10%, (iii) 5.5% if project O&M expenses increase by 10%, and (iv) 5.7% if project 
completion  is  delayed  by  1  year.  Inclusion  of  estimated  carbon  offset  revenues  up  to  2020 
would,  at  a  conservative  estimate,  improve  the  FIRR  to  7.2%  and  the  FNPV  to  CNY1,045.3 
million  and  would  further  strengthen  the  Project's  financial  viability  and  improve  its  cash  flow. 
The financial analysis of the Project is in Appendix 11. 
 
B. 
 
47. 
Analysis  of  financial  performance  was  done  only  for  CHNG.  Greengen  and  HTICL  are 
new  companies  with  little  historical  data.  An  analysis  of  CHNG’s  financial  statements  for  the 
past 4 years was done following ADB's Financial Management and Analysis of Projects.37 The 
audited  financial  statements  of  CHNG  show  that  the  company’s  financial  condition  has  been 
fairly sound except in 2008, when the global financial crisis significantly affected its operations. 
That was a difficult year for CHNG, mainly due to low demand and lower regulated tariffs, which 
subsequently increased in early 2009. Unlike the consistently good financial performance in all 
previous years, the company sustained a net loss of CNY6.78 billion (4.5% of sales) in 2008.38 
Its  financial  performance  will  continue  to  be  closely  monitored  during  project  implementation. 
More data and information on financial management assessment and financial performance and 
projections of project enterprises are in Appendix 12.  
 
48. 
The review of CHNG and HTICL financial management capacity and practices indicates 
that the current systems, policies and standards, and training programs on general accounting 
and finance meet good national and international standards. CHNG's capital structure is robust, 
with shareholders' equity comprising over 40% of its capital structure. However, it is noted that 
the  company  has  embarked  on  a  very  large  capacity  expansion,  which  doubled  its  installed 
capacity in the 3 years after 2005. This expansion, combined with the large investment needed 
to meet environmental regulations and the requirements of energy efficiency and conservation 
in coal-fired power plants, eroded its capital structure and reduced the equity position to about 
33%  in  2005  and  28%  in  2008.  CHNG  is  expected  to  reassess  its  capital  structure  in 
consultation with the Government and seek more equity injection.  
 
49. 
in Supplementary Appendix C.  
 
C. 
 
50. 
The  electricity  demand  forecast  for  Tianjin  considered  trends,  structural  changes, 
efficiency  improvements,  GDP  growth,  and  other  planned  economic  developments  affecting 
demand. Electricity demand was conservatively estimated to grow at 8% in 2011–2015 and 6% 
in 2015–2025. The estimates suggest that there will be continued strong demand for electricity 
in Tianjin, and the Project will provide incremental electricity to meet part of it.  
 
The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the Project was calculated to assess its 
51. 
economic  viability.  Capital  costs  and  O&M  costs  were  considered.  Appropriate  conversion 
factors  were  used  to  convert  financial  values  into  economic  values.  Values  are  expressed  in 
2009 local currency. The quantified benefits of the Project considered in the economic analysis 
included incremental energy supply through willingness to pay. This yielded an EIRR of 16.49%.

Environmental Benefits and Impacts  

The  EIRR  is  conservatively  calculated,  as  it  takes  into  account  only  the  main  benefits  and 
includes  all  project-related  costs.  Sensitivity  and  risk  analyses  simulating  adverse  scenarios 
were  carried  out,  and  the  EIRR  was  found  to  be  stable  and  robust.  Appendix  13 presents  the 
economic analysis of the Project. 
 
D. 
 
The  Project  is  classified  as  environment  category  A  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
52. 
environmental  classification  criteria  under 
its  Environment  Policy  (2002).  The  project 
environmental  impact  assessment  (EIA),  prepared  by  the  Tianjin  Environment  Protection 
Research  Institute,  was  approved  by  the  State  Environmental  Protection  Administration  (now 
the  Ministry  of  Environment  Protection)  in  July  2007  and  uploaded  to  the  ADB  website  on  14 
April  2008.  A  summary  of  environmental  impacts  and  the  implementation  of  the  EMP  is  in 
Appendix 14. The full EIA report is in Supplementary Appendix D.  
 
53. 
Coal-fired IGCC power plants substantially reduce emissions of major air pollutants like 
SO2,  NOx,  total  suspended  particulates,  and  CO2  when  compared  with  conventional  power 
plants. In comparison to a conventional coal-fired power plant of 300 MW capacity, the avoided 
annual  emissions  from  the  IGCC  plant  are  estimated  at  43  t  of  total  suspended  particulate, 
1,237 t of SO2, and 3,325 t of NOx. On completion, the Project will save 134,000 t of coal per 
year of operation. It will prevent an estimated 372,000 t of CO2 emissions annually and result in, 
associated  global  climate  benefits.  The  Project  will  use  35%  less  cooling  water  than  an 
alternative conventional plant and generate significantly less slag.  
 
The IGCC plant is proposed to be located in an industrial area on land reclaimed from 
54. 
the  Bohai  Sea.  The  environmental  value  of  the  land  and  its  surroundings  is  poor.  The 
environmental  impacts  of  the  Project,  mainly  limited  to  construction,  are  dust  emissions,  soil 
erosion,  accidental  spillage,  noise  impacts,  and  waste  generation.  The  summary  EIA  reported 
that the adverse environmental impacts of the Project can be minimized to acceptable levels by 
implementing  adequately  funded  environmental  management  activities.  Project  cost  estimates 
include CNY88.25 million for environmental protection. The project monitoring plan and counter 
supervision  of  all  construction  by  CHNG  and  its  contracted  environmental  representative  is 
to  ensure  compliance  with  ADB  policies  and  procedures  and  government 
designed 
environmental  legislation,  policies,  and  guidelines.  The  first  annual  environmental  compliance 
report  was  submitted  in  July  2009.  As  project  construction  was  in  a  preliminary  stage, 
environment  impacts  were  minimal  and  complied  with  the  agreed  EMP.  To  further  strengthen 
compliance, ADB will closely monitor construction through regular missions.

Project Risks and Mitigation Measures   

F. 
 
56. 
All  the  major  components  of  the  IGCC  power  plant  have  been  pilot  tested  or 
commercially  established  and  are  in  successful  operation  in  the  PRC.  However,  these 
components  have  not  yet  been  combined  in  a  reliable,  industrial-size  IGCC  power  plant. 
Therefore,  the  risks  involved  in  this  project  being  a  first-of-a-kind  risk  demonstration  project, 
exists, especially during the first 2 years of operation. The risk has been substantially reduced 
with the help of a $5 million grant from ADB's CCF.  
 
The  coal  gasifier  is  a  significant  departure  from  a  conventional  coal-fired  power  plant. 
57. 
Coal gasification is a mature technology, and about 15 similar coal gasifiers as proposed for the 
Project  (2,000  t/day)  are  extensively  used  in  various  chemical  industry  plants  in  the  PRC.  At 
least two gasifiers of the same capacity are installed in the Tianjin Harbor Industrial Park next to 
the  Project  site,  in  the  Tianjin  Alkali  Plant.  The  Project  will  use  a  domestically  developed  coal 
gasifier  with  a  capacity  of  36  t/day  using  coal  of  the  same  quality,  a  prototype  of  which  was 
designed and constructed by TPRI in 2006. This prototype gasifier was extensively tested and 
has  been  successfully  in  operation  for  over  10,000  hours.  The  Council  of  Scientific  and 
Industrial  Research  Organizations  in  Australia  further  tested  this  prototype  gasifier  using 
imported coal and found it satisfactory. The scaling-up of the prototype is an industry norm. To 
further improve the reliability of the syngas supply for the Project, a syngas connection with the 
Tianjin  Alakali  Plant  is  included,  which  will  provide  backup  in  case  the  gasifier  breaks  down, 
thus ensuring the reliability of electricity supply from the Project. 
 
58. 
The  potential  risks  related  to  the  type  or  quantity  of  coal  supplied  to  the  IGCC  power 
plant  is  minimal.  The  coal  for  the  Project  will  be  supplied  by  Shenhua  Group,  the  largest  coal 
producer in the country and an equity partner in Greengen. The coal will be supplied from the 
Shenhua's  Shenfu-Dongsheng  and  Yitai  No.  4  coalfields  in  Inner  Mongolia  and  Shanxi  and 
transported  by  railway  to  the  coal-unloading  system  in  the  Tianjin  Alkali  Plant  adjacent  to  the 
Project. The railway connection and coal-unloading system is already constructed. No additional 
railway  or  coal-unloading  facility  will  be  built  for  the  IGCC  power  plant.  HTICL  and  Shenhua 
signed  a  long-term  coal  purchase  agreement  for  the  Project  in  October  2008.  CHNG  is  the 
largest generator in the PRC and has long-term contractual relationships with coal suppliers for 
many power plants across the PRC.  
 
59. 
Project  implementation  risks  are  minimal.  The  Project  is  fully  supported  by  MOST  and 
NDRC and listed as one of the major projects for scientific development in the 11th FYP. The 
Project's  feasibility  report  was  rigorously  reviewed  by  NDRC  and  other  experts  and  finally 
approved  on  9  May  2009.  All  other  relevant  national  approvals  are  in  place.  Greengen  has 
acquired  the  project  site  and  its  possible  future  extension  for  a  scaled-up  IGCC  plant  and  an 
integrated  IGCC–CCS  plant.  The  key  procurement  of  the  gas  turbine  and  coal  gasifier  was 
finalized  before  feasibility  approval  to  improve  the  Project's  cost  estimates  and  refine  the 
feasibility  report. 39  Construction  work  was  formally  launched  on  6  July  2009.  Advanced 
contracting following ADB guidelines is ongoing, with most procurement expected to be finalized 
by mid-2010. The Project readiness filter is in Appendix 16. 
 
60. 
The capacity of CHNG and HTICL is sufficient for the construction and O&M of the first 
IGCC  power  plant  in  the  PRC.  CHNG  pioneers  clean  coal  technologies  in  the  PRC.  It  has 
successfully led the development of supercritical and USC technologies in power plants, which 
                                                 
39 Early  finalization  of  these  critical  components  was  essential  to  ascertain  the  interfaces  and  proceed  with 
preliminary design with refined cost estimates. The coal gasifier is a proprietary item, and international competitive 
bidding was conducted for the gas turbine package. As these procurements were finalized much earlier, they are 
not eligible for ADB financing or included in the procurement plan.  

 

 18 

 

have promptly achieved their rated performance capacities. The latest USC plants are on a par 
with  or  better  than  similar  international  plants.  The  staff  of  CHNG  and  Greengen,  who  has 
extensive  previous  experience  in  operating  large,  modern  coal-fired  power  plants,  will  be 
engaged  to  operate  and  maintain  the  Project.  CHNG  and  Greengen  are  extensively  recruiting 
and  training  young  graduates  with  chemical  engineering  backgrounds  to  complement  its 
extensive  thermal  power  plant  expertise.  The  suppliers'  assistance  with  O&M  (para.  24)  will 
further strengthen the O&M capacity of the project staff, enhancing sustainability.    
 
61. 
Electricity tariffs in the PRC are regulated and approved by NDRC for individual power 
plants only towards the end of their construction. In the case of the Project, the feasibility report 
flagged a higher tariff of CNY0.56/kWh than the CNY0.38/kWh approved for conventional coal-
fired power plants by NDRC in the project area. The Project is financially viable at this tariff of 
CNY0.56/kWh. Since NDRC has rigorously reviewed the feasibility report and approved it, the 
associated risk of any lower tariff than in the feasibility report is minimal.

INTEGRATED GASIFICATION COMBINED CYCLE TECHNOLOGY 

Coal Gasification 

 
A. 
 
Coal gasification has existed longer than coal-fired electricity generation. Prior to the use 
1. 
of natural gas, coal gasification was used to produce gas for lighting and heating in the United 
States  and  the  United  Kingdom  in  the  early  19th  century.  Coal  gasification  was  used  in  many 
industrial  applications  because  of  its  abundance  and  low  price,  replacing  natural  gas.  In  the 
1970s,  an  energy  crisis  brought  resurgent  interest  in  synthesis  gas  (syngas)  as  an  energy 
alternative.  Decades  of  research  and  development  in  coal  gasification  have  created  a  mature 
technology  that  is  currently  being  scaled-up  for  clean  energy  and  chemical  feedstock 
production.  
 
2. 
In  coal  gasification,  steam,  and  oxygen  are  injected  under  high  temperature  and 
pressure  into  a  coal  gasifier  to  produce  combustible  syngas—a  mixture  of  carbon  monoxide, 
hydrogen and other gaseous compounds. After being cleaned of sulfide and impurities, syngas 
can  be  burned  in  high-efficiency  gas  turbines  to  generate  electricity.  Coal  gasification  is  a 
flexible  technology  to  produce  hydrogen,  which  is  recognized  as  a  potent  environmentally 
cleaner future source of energy. By the end of 2007, global gasification capacity had grown to 
56,238 megawatts (MW) thermal of syngas output from 144 plants.1 In the People's Republic of 
China (PRC), coal gasification has been used for many decades, and 44 operating plants now 
convert coal and petroleum residues into a variety of chemicals, fertilizers, and gaseous fuels. 
Current data show that the world's syngas capacity is projected to grow by another 17,135 MW 
thermal from 2008 to 2010, which is an increase of over 30%. Six of the 10 planned plants will 
be in the PRC, all processing coal to produce chemicals, fertilizers, and methanol.  
 
B. 
 
Integrated  gasification  combined  cycle  (IGCC)  is  a  technology  that  combines  coal 
3. 
gasification and combined cycle power generation. In a combined cycle power plant, syngas is 
burned  in  a  high-efficiency  gas  turbine  to  generate  the  first  source  of  electricity.  To  improve 
efficiency, heat is recovered from both the gasification process and the gas turbine exhaust to 
produce steam. This steam is then used to drive a steam turbine to generate the second source 
of  electricity.  Thus,  IGCC  integrates  a  coal  gasification  unit  with  a  combined  cycle  unit  that 
combines  a  gas  turbine  with  a  steam  turbine.  This  has  higher  thermal  efficiency  than 
conventional  pulverized  coal.  The  thermal  efficiency  of  IGCC  is  expected  to  reach  50%  or 
higher, compared with 34%–40% in a conventional pulverized coal power plant; future concepts 
that  incorporates  a  fuel  cell  could  achieve  efficiency  nearly  twice  today's  coal  combustion 
technologies.2  
 
With growing concern about rising CO2 emissions, especially from large coal-fired power 
4. 
plants,  coal  gasification  is  gaining  momentum  with  its  higher  efficiency,  emission  reductions, 
and mature technology. Many new plants have recently been announced.

5.

the waste ash of pulverized coal power plants that must be put into landfills, occupying useful 
land  and  potentially  contaminating  groundwater.  Table  A2.1  compares  the  environmental

The high cost of IGCC is the biggest obstacle to its integration in the power market. A 
6. 
recent estimate indicates that the capital cost for IGCC is as high as $2,500 per kilowatt, about 
twice  the  capital  cost  of  pulverized  coal.1 Table  A2.2  lists  the  major  coal-fired  and/or  petcoke-
based  IGCC  plants  in  the  world.  Most  IGCC  power  plants  in  operation  are  of  approximately 
200–300  MW  capacity.  The  Sarlux  IGCC  at  the  Saras  oil  refinery  in  Sardinia  is  the  largest 
operating  IGCC  to  date,  producing  550  MW  of  electric  power.  With  growing  concerns  about 
climate  change  caused  by  CO2  emissions,  and  stricter  emissions  requirements  from  local 
environmental authorities especially in terms of mercury removal, IGCC plants are finding favor 
with  project developers  in  Europe  and  the  United  States, where  multiple  IGCC  plants  of up  to 
800 MW capacity have been announced. IGCC also offers a unique advantage in burning lower-
grade  coal  and  coal  blended  with  biomass  in  the  gasifier,  which  suggests  even  wider 
applicability for the technology.

C. 
 
7. 
Historically,  the  primary  focus  of  clean  coal  technologies  was  on  sulfur  dioxide  and 
particulates. More recently, the focus has turned to near-zero emission technologies intended to 
take  the  carbon  out  of  coal  combustion.  Demonstration  projects  already  funded  include  oxy 
combustion and post-combustion capture. Many other projects, small and large, are in progress 
around the world, including in the PRC and other developing countries.  
  
8. 
All  of  the  currently  available  technologies  (i.e.,  pre-combustion,  oxy  combustion,  and 
post-combustion) for separating a concentrated CO2 stream from a large power-generation plant 
require both significant additional equipment and a significantly increased input of energy, when 
compared  with  technologies  without  capture.  This  requires  the  development  of  economical 
methods  of  carbon  sequestration.  A  key  driver  for  coal  gasification  is  the  innate  capability  of 
gasification  technology  to  separate  and  capture  CO2  most  effectively.  Coal  gasification  units 
could  be  modified  to  separate  CO2  generated  from  the  syngas  before  combustion  and  thus 
effectively  address  the  problem  of  reducing  greenhouse  gas  emissions.  Therefore,  IGCC  has 
been viewed as the most cost-effective platform for long-term capture.2  
 
9. 
Carbon  dioxide  capture  and  storage  (CCS)  or  capture-ready  discussions  have  often 
been confined to IGCC  plants, with an implied or actual assumption that capture could not be 
retrofitted to other types of power plants, principally pulverized coal, or that no special provisions 
were needed to make such combustion units capture-ready.3 This view is also implicit in United 
States energy policy, 4 as evidenced by its funding of IGCC.,5 With restrictions on CO2 emissions 
in  the  future,  IGCC  represents  an  important  advancement  for  power  generation.  Public 
information identifies 50 projects for United States operation beyond 2010.6 
 
D. 
 
10. 
Since  the  early  1990s,  the  PRC  has  been  actively  pursuing  clean  coal  technologies. 
There is a growing base for new high-efficiency supercritical and ultra-supercritical (USC) coal-
fired units in operation in the PRC. By the end of 2007, seven domestically manufactured 1,000 
MW  class  and  two  600  MW  class  USC  units  had  been  commissioned,  in  addition  to  226 
supercritical units with 600 MW. These efficient units greatly changed the paradigm of thermal

generation  capacity.7 Because  IGCC  has  the  potential  to  achieve  even  higher  efficiency  than 
supercritical  and  USC  pulverized  units,  it  has  been  listed  as  the  top  priority  for  technology 
development  in  China's  Agenda  21. 8  However,  IGCC  is  still  in  the  early  stages  of 
commercialization,  and  further  research,  development,  and  operating  experience  is  needed 
before the technology can reach the scale and reliability needed for economic competitiveness. 
In  1994,  the  Government  of  the  PRC  established  the  state-level  IGCC  Steering  Committee 
consisting of six government agencies to manage the development of IGCC technology. Since 
then, the Government has continued its effort to build an IGCC demonstration plant.  
 
11. 
The  PRC  has  the  potential  to  be  the  single  biggest  market  for  IGCC  because  of  its 
consistently large capacity addition over the past 3 years and anticipated strong growth. In view 
of  the  PRC's  strong  domestic  manufacturing  capacity  and  abundant  low-cost  and  high-quality 
human  resources,  the  capital  cost  of  IGCC  in  the  PRC  will  very  likely  be  cheaper  than  in  the 
United  States  and  Europe.  Previous  energy  sector  practices  in  the  PRC  demonstrate  that  the 
development  and  mass  production  of  new  technologies  are  cost-effective  in  the  global  joint 
effort  against  climate  change,  especially  in  the  areas  of  energy  efficiency  improvement  and 
emission reduction. 
 
E. 
 
To  support  the  development  of  IGCC  and  CCS  technologies,  the  PRC  announced  in 
12. 
2005 its GreenGen program, which was launched in December 2005 with a mandate to lead the 
research, development, and demonstration of cleaner coal technologies leading to a near-zero 
emission  coal-fired  power  plant  by  2015.  Greengen  has  identified  a  phased  approach.  In  the 
first  phase,  it  plans  to  implement  a  250  MW  coal-fired  IGCC  plant  at  Tianjin.  The  Project  is 
supported  by  the  Ministry  of  Science  and  Technology  and  the  National  Development  and 
Reform Commission and is listed as one of the major projects for scientific development in the 
11th  Five-Year  Plan  under  the  National  High-tech  Research  and  Development  Program.  The 
Project  is  located  in  Tianjin  Harbor  Industrial  Park  and  will  be  the  first  IGCC  demonstration 
project in the PRC. On completion, it will supply base-load electricity to the local grid and steam 
and  heat  to  facilities  in  Tianjin  Harbor  Industrial  Park.  Construction  of  the  Project  has  started 
and will be completed by June 2012.

F. 
 
14. 
Tianjin IGCC power plant is located in Tianjin Harbor Industrial Park phase I, in Tianjin 
Binhai New Area and adjacent to the east side of Tianjin Alkali Plant. Tianjin Harbor Industrial 
Park is located in Tanggu district of Tianjin, 46 kilometers (km) from Tianjin city center, 38 km 
from Tianjin International Airport, and 2 km from Tianjin port. The industrial park is planned to 
cover  80  square  km.  The  first  phase  of  the  industrial  park  is  mainly  for  the  chemical  and 
petrochemical  industries,  while  the  second  phase  is  primarily  for  shipbuilding  and  ship-repair, 
equipment manufacture, metal processing, and some manufacturing. The third phase will also 
include major chemical industries.  
 
The  North-West  Electricity  Research  Institute  is  the  overall  designer  of  the  Project, 
15. 
supported  by  Thermal  Power  Research  Institute,  Xian  and  Wuhan  Engineering  Company  Ltd.  
The key components of the Tianjin IGCC Power Plant include (i) a 2,000 tons/day coal gasifier; 
(ii)  a  172.8  MW  gas  turbine  generator;  (iii)  a  94.5  MW  steam  turbine  generator;  and  (iv)  200 
kilovolt  (kV)  gas  insulated  switchgear.  On  completion,  the  Tianjin  IGCC  power  plant  will 
generate 1,470 gigawatt-hours of electricity annually, which will be evacuated through a 220 kV 
transmission line to an existing substation for connection with the Tianjin power grid. The Tianjin 
power grid is connected to the North China Power Grid through 500 kV transmission lines.

2. 
While the PRC has been taking steps to diversify energy resources, especially nuclear 
power and non-hydro renewables, it remains heavily dependent on coal as primary energy and 
fuel for power generation. Coal accounts for 70% of total primary energy consumption, which is 
far above the world average of 26%.2 Non-hydro renewable energy has been expanding rapidly 
since  2006  but  faces  the  challenges  of  higher  cost  than  coal-fired  power  plants  and  long 
transmission lines. In 2008, thermal power generation accounted for 80.9% of power generation 
in the country. Hydropower constituted 16.4%, and nuclear, wind, and other energy resources 
contributed the remaining 2.7%, including less than 0.5% from wind.   
 
Electricity  consumption  is  dominated  by  energy-intensive  heavy  industries,  including 
3. 
cement, metallurgy, petrochemicals, chemicals, clay and porcelain, glass, papermaking, textiles,  
and  other  manufacturing  industries.  Heavy  industry  alone  accounts  for  61%  of  total  electricity 
consumption, while residential consumption is only 12%.  
 
4. 
Energy efficiency has been a high priority for PRC policy makers and has gained even 
greater  prominence  over  the  past  few  years  as  the  main  approach  to  addressing  both  energy 
security  and  environmental  concerns. 3  The  Government  of  the  PRC  has  identified  power 
generation  as  a  priority  sector  to  be  targeted  to  improve  energy  efficiency.  Compared  with 
international best practice, there is still large scope for improvement.  
 
B. 
 
5. 
Sustained  and  impressive  growth  for  more  than  2  decades  is  testimony  to  the  sector's 
ability  to  meet  the  need  for  additional  capacity.  The  Government  has  set  out  to  transform  the

Sector Reforms   

sector from a centrally planned structure to a market-based system. In 2002, the former State 
Power  Company  was  dismantled.  Its  generating  assets  were  reallocated  to  five  generating 
companies:  China  Datang  Corporation,  China  Huadian  Corporation,  China  Guodian 
Corporation,  and  China  Power  Investment  Corporation  and  its  transmission  and  distribution 
assets were split between two grid companies: State Grid and China Southern Grid. 
 
6. 
The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) is the sector's top planning 
and  regulatory  agency.  Recognizing  the  strategic  importance  of  energy  to  the  economy,  the 
State  Council  upgraded  the  Energy  Bureau  of  NDRC  to  become  the  National  Energy 
Administration  in  2008.  Although  the  administration  is  still  under  the  supervision  of  NDRC,  it 
reports  directly  to  the  State  Council.  The  State  Electricity  Regulatory  Commission  has  since 
2003 overseen regulating the electricity subsector.  
 
C. 
 
7. 
As other energy subsectors, i.e., coal, oil, and gas, have been considerably deregulated 
and become more flexible in determining prices, electricity is still in transition. Current electricity 
pricing  regulation  needs  to  be  understood  in  the  broader  context  of  its  single-buyer  model  for 
power transactions. In general, generators sell power to the grid companies at regulated prices, 
and the grid companies sell the power to end-users also at regulated prices. Although the State 
Electricity Regulatory Commission was established in 2003, NDRC still sets the electricity tariff 
based on the costs of power generation, transmission, and distribution, including a reasonable 
rate of return on investments. NDRC has gradually reformed the electricity tariff structure in the 
past  few  years,  in  part  to  encourage  improvements  in  efficiency.  The  prices  paid  to  new 
generators are set according to the technologies in use in each province. For example, within a 
province, all new coal-fired plants with desulfurization are paid the same price, which is different 
from the price paid to other technologies such as hydropower. The efficiency of energy-intensive 
industries  was  reviewed  and  categorized  by  energy  efficiency.  Price  discounts  have  been 
abolished  and  surcharges  increased  for  the  least  efficient.  This  pricing  policy  has  been  quite 
effective.  By  2006,  about  1,200  high  energy-consuming  enterprises  were  understood  to  have 
shut  down,  suspended  operations,  invested  in  energy  efficiency,  or  changed  production 
processes. 
 
D. 
 
8. 
The PRC electricity industry needs constructive restructuring and more rapid movement 
towards  market  mechanisms.  Some  key  initiatives  like  efficiency-based  load  dispatch  and 
electricity markets are being piloted and are expected to be gradually introduced under the 12th 
Five-Year Plan 2011–2015. With growing concerns about global warming and climate change, 
the  challenge  will  be  to  reduce  the  carbon  intensity  of  its  electricity  generation  significantly  by 
2020. Future electricity policies have to encourage technology innovations and the efficient use 
of  limited  resources  and  balance  them  with  long-term  social  welfare.  This  may  mean  a 
combination of energy-efficient technologies being powered by a range of renewable and fossil 
fuels.  The  future  electricity  policy  framework  should  include  a  mechanism  through  which 
electricity firms are pushed to pursue higher production efficiency.

Appendix 4 

EXTERNAL ASSISTANCE AND ITS LESSONS  
 

External Assistance 

A. 
 
Since 1987, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has approved assistance for more than 
1. 
30  energy  projects  totaling  $3.6  billion  to  the  Government  of  the  People's  Republic  of  China 
(PRC). The assistance has been divided evenly between projects that increased energy supply 
($1.8  billion)  and  those  that  improved  the  environment  ($1.8  billion).  About  47%  was  for 
hydropower, pumped-storage, and coal-mine methane projects; 20% for transmission lines; and 
33% for thermal power. Since 2000, more attention has been paid to environment and climate 
change issues, and there has been a focus on projects in renewable energy, energy efficiency, 
and  capture  of  coal-mine  and  coal-bed  methane.  These  projects  not  only  helped  the  PRC 
expand its power supply capacity but also directly reduced coal consumption and consequently 
reduced emissions of pollutants, including greenhouse gases linked to global climate change. 
 
2. 
ADB  has  also  provided  about  100  technical  assistance  (TA)  projects  for  the  energy 
sector, costing about $50 million, to help prepare projects, provide policy advice, and build the 
institutional  capability  of  utilities  (power,  district  heat,  and  urban  gas  supply)  that  are  the 
implementing agencies of ADB loans. ADB provided TA projects to help restructure the power 
subsector, formulate power-pricing strategy, improve the power-planning process, and establish 
the  State  Electricity  Regulatory  Commission.  TA  also  covered  clean  production, 1  energy 
conservation,2 energy efficiency,3 and environmental management.4 ADB is currently conducting 
a  comprehensive  study  jointly  with  the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission  to 
analyze  the  opportunities  and  challenges  for  promoting  energy  efficiency  and  renewable 
energy. 5  It  will  make  practical  policy  recommendations  to  overcome  barriers,  facilitate  the 
implementation of development strategies and industrial policies, explore innovative approaches 
to utilizing external assistance, and identify key provinces and projects for piloting high-impact 
clean energy projects. 
 
3. 
ADB  has  also  extended  two  project  loans  totaling  $90  million  to  the  private  sector  for 
power  generation.  Its  Private  Sector  Operations  Department  is  now  providing  a  program  of 
partial credit risk guarantees with an overall limit of CNY800 million to cover an agreed portion 
(about 48% of the portfolio) of principal repayment of loans extended by selected partner banks 
to finance energy efficiency projects. This innovative mechanism can mobilize domestic banks 
to  provide  loans  for  energy  efficiency  projects  by  reducing  performance  uncertainties  and 
sharing credit risks.  
 
4. 
Other major multilateral agencies active in the PRC also support the energy sector. The 
World  Bank  has  been  the  largest  multilateral  funder  for  PRC  power  sector.  Since  the  early 
1990s,  it  has  provided  more  than  $6.2  billion  to  finance  25  projects,  most  of  which  are  large 
thermal  and  hydropower  generation  projects  and  power  transmission  and  distribution  projects.
