 Appendix 4 

31

In  recent  years,  the  World  Bank  provided  loans  to  support  the  Government’s  efforts  in  urban 
environment improvement, renewable energy, energy efficiency, and developing energy service 
companies  in  the  PRC. 6  The  World  Bank  also  provided  TA  projects  for  power  subsector 
restructuring  and  heating  subsector  reforms.  The  United  Nations  Development  Programme  is 
providing assistance for studies regarding options for power sector restructuring and promoting 
energy  conservation.  The  ongoing  China  End-Use  Energy  Efficiency  Project  aims  to  promote 
energy  efficiency  in  major  energy-consuming  sectors  such  as  industries  and  building 
construction.  
 
5. 
Among  bilateral  sources,  the  Japan  Bank  for  International  Cooperation  is  the  largest 
source  of  external  assistance  for  the  PRC’s  power  subsector.  It  has  provided  concessional 
loans totaling CNY438 billion for 14 power projects through its official development assistance 
window.  It  has  also  provided  special  credits  to  major  cities  to  improve  their  environment  by 
installing emission-control devices and equipment in power plants and factories and by building 
water-treatment facilities. It is considering shifting its traditional focus of assistance in the power 
subsector  from  hydropower  and  thermal  power  generation  to  energy  conservation  and 
renewable energy, particularly in the western region. German development cooperation through 
KfW  has  approved  approximately  $400  million  in  mixed  credits,  mostly  for  power  plants  and 
turbine-modernization  projects.  It  also  supported  the  Government  in  energy  efficiency  and 
renewable energy development. Other bilateral sources providing export credits or mixed credits 
in  the  energy  sector  include  Australia,  Canada,  Denmark,  France,  Italy,  Spain,  the  United 
Kingdom, and the United States.  
 
6. 
Close  cooperation  among  development  partners  has  been  pursued  through  regular 
meetings. 7  ADB  has  established  a  working  relationship  with  the  World  Bank  and  other 
multilateral and bilateral agencies toward addressing policy issues and coordinating lending and 
TA  operations.  Both  ADB  and  the  World  Bank  emphasize  the  importance  of  energy  efficiency 
improvement,  promoting  clean  energy,  environmental  protection,  and  a  greater  role  for  the 
private sector in clean energy financing. Annual aid-coordination meetings are held in Beijing to 
share strategies.  
 
B. 
 
7. 
ADB’s  experience  with  energy  projects  in  the  PRC  has  been  positive.  Projects  are 
generally  well  designed  and  smoothly  implemented,  though  front-end  delays  have  occurred  in 
some  projects.  Success  is  attributed  to  extensive  preparation  prior  to  ADB  intervention,  high 
sense of local ownership, effective leadership in project management offices, and timely policy 
and enterprise reforms. The front-end delays in loan signing and loan effectiveness did not lead 
to  unsatisfactory  performance.  The  Government  has  implemented  reforms  on  investment 
regulations  that  simplify  approval  procedures  and  delegate  some  approving  authority  to 
provincial  governments.  ADB  has  worked  closely  with  the  Government  to  harmonize  the  two 
approval procedures to minimize project start-up and implementation delays. 
 
The  implementation  performance  of  the  energy  portfolio  is  satisfactory. 8  Project 
8. 
completion and performance evaluation reports for ADB-financed projects in the PRC highlight 
the (i) need to improve financial reporting; (ii) need for more attention to environmental matters;

(iii)  advisability  of  using  larger  boiler  turbine  units;  and  (iv)  necessity  for  capacity  building,  not 
only for project preparation, but also to train staff in operation and management.   
 
9. 
The  World  Bank  review  of  experience  in  energy  efficiency  has  shown  that  projects 
should seek to test a variety of business models to achieve energy savings. In particular, access 
to  appropriate  project  financing  that  supports  energy  service  company  transactions  should  be 
integral to project design. It suggests that procurement and disbursement procedures should be 
simplified, as they increase transaction costs and discourage energy efficiency.9 
 
10. 
These  lessons  were  taken  into  account  when  designing  and  preparing  the  Project. 
During  preparation,  lessons  were  addressed  by  (i)  thoroughly  reviewing  project  readiness  on 
key  factors  that  may  delay  start-up,  (ii)  carefully  assessing  institutional  capacity  and 
strengthening measures to improve corporate governance, (iii) providing conservative estimates 
of the expected tariff consistent with existing  policies and practices, and (iv) setting up project 
implementing units with autonomy for operations and procurement decisions.

INFORMATION ON THE EXPORT-IMPORT BANK OF CHINA 

Business Scope 

Onlending of Foreign Loans 

 
A. 
 
1. 
The  Export-Import  Bank  of  China  (EXIM  Bank)  is  a  state  policy  bank  of  the  People's 
Republic of China (PRC) under the direct leadership of the State Council. It was established in 
1994  and  is  solely  owned  by  the  Government  of  the  PRC.  EXIM  Bank  is  headquartered  in 
Beijing  and  has  over  10  business  branches  and  domestic  representative  offices,  as  well  as 
three overseas representative offices, in Johannesburg, Paris, and St. Petersburg. It maintains 
correspondent relationships with more than 300 overseas banks worldwide. 
 
2. 
EXIM Bank plays an important role in supporting the PRC's foreign trade and economic 
development.  It  provides  policy  financing  for  exports  as  well  as  for  imports  of  mechanical, 
electronic, and new high-technology products and equipment, and it has provided assistance for 
offshore construction contracts as well as overseas investment projects. EXIM Bank is the major 
onlending  bank  of  foreign  government  and  international  financial  institution  loans  and  is 
mandated as the sole lending bank for the PRC's concessionary loans. 
 
B. 
 
3. 
In  the  face  of  challenges  arising  from  reduced  loan  amounts  offered  by  some  foreign 
governments  and  fierce  market  competition  for  traditional  onlending  products,  EXIM  Bank 
refocused its business philosophy and adopted measures to remain competitive. It took active 
steps  to  tap  growth  potential  in  the  onlending  business  by  adding  new  countries,  businesses, 
and product varieties to its list. Utilizing foreign funds, EXIM Bank has supported key projects in 
infrastructure,  medical  care,  education,  and  environment  protection  and  has  contributed  to 
implementing the national strategy of developing the western region of the PRC. In 2007, EXIM 
Bank  signed  onlending  agreements  with  a  total  value  of  $950  million  for  47  projects.  Total 
outstanding loans at end-2007 were worth $18.94 billion. To date, EXIM Bank has onlent loans 
provided  by  22  foreign  governments  and  five  international  financial  institutions,  including  the 
World Bank and European Investment Bank. 
 
4. 
EXIM  Bank  categorizes  its  onlending  activities  into  three  types  depending  on  the 
classification of the borrower and who is responsible for repayment. It charges a standard fee 
for onlending. The Tianjin Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle Power Plant is classified as 
type I, wherein a state-owned enterprise (China Huaneng Group) under the State Council bears 
repayment  obligation.  EXIM  Bank  charges  an  onlending  fee  of  0.15%  for  the  size  of  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) financing envisioned for the Project.  
 
C. 
 
At the end of 2007, EXIM Bank's total asset value was CNY378.74 billion. Phenomenal 
5. 
growth rates in total assets reached 47.3% in 2005, 26.1% in 2006, and 46.6% in 2007. Profit 
after tax in 2007 was CNY109.4 million. The growth rates in profit after tax were 79.1% in 2005, 
23.2% in 2006, and 23.6% in 2007. EXIM Bank has been, and continues to be, a fast-growing 
entity accompanying rapid economic development in the PRC. 
 
D. 
 
EXIM Bank's international credit ratings are the same as the PRC's sovereign ratings. In 
6. 
2008, its credit rating from Moody's Investors Service was A1, from Standard & Poor's A+, and 
from Fitch A+, signifying investment-grade credit quality.

General 

Revenues and Costs 

 
A. 
 
1. 
This appendix describes the notes and assumptions used in the financial analysis of the 
Tianjin Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle Power Plant Project. The financial analysis was 
prepared in accordance with the Asian Development Bank Financial Management and Analysis 
of  Projects.1 All  costs  and  prices  are  expressed  in  constant  2009  prices.  The  economic  life  of 
the Project is estimated at 25 years with residual value assumed for the civil works and land-use 
right.  The  financial  operation  of  the  project  implementing  agency,  Huaneng  Tianjin  IGCC  Co. 
Ltd., was projected based on the assumptions described in Appendix 12. The projected financial 
statements are shown in Supplementary Appendix C. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
Revenues  from  the  Project  will  be  derived  from  the  sale  of electricity  generated  by  the 
power plant based on projected yearly net generation of 249 gigawatt-hours in 2011 and 1,245 
GWh from 2015 and the tariff of CNY0.56 assumed in the project feasibility study approved by 
the National Development and Reform Commission. A tariff in this range is a major factor in the 
Project's viability.  
 
The  capital  cost  includes  physical  contingencies  but  excludes  price  contingencies  and 
3. 
financial  charges  during  development.  Operating  and  maintenance  costs  include  personnel 
salaries and welfare costs, plant and equipment maintenance costs, administration, insurance, 
taxes, and other expenses. 
 
C.

The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  of  the  Project  was  calculated  as  shown  in 
Table  A11.1.  The  FIRR  is  6.4%,  higher  than  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  (WACC) 
estimated at 3.7%, and the financial net present value is CNY820.9 million at this WACC. The 
Project  is  considered  financially  feasible.  Sensitivity  analysis  shows  that  the  FIRR  is  robust 
under various adverse conditions, as shown in Table A11.2.

2. 
CHNG is a state-owned enterprise (SOE) under the direct jurisdiction of the Government 
of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and is a leading group in the PRC's power sector. It 
was established in 1985 with registered capital of CNY20 billion. In December 2002, when the 
PRC's  power  sector  was  reorganized,  CHNG  received  about  one-fifth  of  the  assets  of  the 
dissolved  State  Power  Corporation,  along  with  the  four  other  state-owned  power-generating 
companies.1 CHNG has developed into a large group comprised of wholly owned or controlled 
subsidiaries  with  regional  branches  and  offices  both  in  the  PRC  and  abroad.  CHNG  conducts 
business independently and bears full responsibility for its profits and losses. It has a diversified 
business  portfolio  with  power  generation  at  its  core.  One  of  its  biggest  subsidiaries,  Huaneng 
Power International, is listed on the Hong Kong and New York stock exchanges. 
 
3. 
CHNG lists the following as its business areas: (i) management of its state-owned assets 
and subsidiaries; (ii) investment, construction, operation, and management of power-generation 
assets  and  the  production  and  sale  of  power  and  heat;  (iii)  investment,  construction,  and 
transportation,  renewable  energy, 
operation  of  businesses 
environment  protection,  trade,  and  fuel;  (iv)  businesses  associated  with  foreign  trade  and 
international  cooperation;  and  (v)  investment  and  financing  in  domestic  and  international 
markets. 
 
4. 
As  of  end-2008,  CHNG's  total  installed  capacity  was  86  gigawatts  (GW),  and  its  2008 
electricity production was 364.5 terrawatt-hours, about 10.5% of the national total, making it the 
largest power producer in the PRC. Its power plants are located in economically vibrant regions 
where  power  demand  is  very  strong.  The  company  attributes  its  success  to  its  strength  in  the 
following areas: (i) advanced equipment, efficient generating units, and steady operations; (ii) a 
high-quality employee base and experienced management team; (iii) a standardized corporate 
governance  structure  and  scientific  decision-making  mechanism;  (iv)  strategically  located 
power-generating  assets  and  bright  market  prospects;  and  (v)  sound  creditworthiness  both 
domestically and internationally and rich experience in capital market operation. 
 
5. 
CHNG  has  a  rigorous  and  sound  accounting  system,  internal  control  procedures,  and 
experienced and qualified financial and internal auditing staff. CHNG is in a position to provide 
to  both  Greengen  and  HTICL  the  guidance  and  monitoring  needed  to  improve  their  financial 
performance and systems for accounting, internal control, and risk management.

B. 

Financial Performance and Projections 

13. 
Financial  performance  can  be  analyzed  only  for  CHNG.  An  analysis  of  the  company’s 
financial statements for the past 4 years was done following ADB's Financial Management and 
Analysis  of  Projects. 3 The  audited  financial  statements  of  CHNG  show  that  the  company’s 
financial condition has been fairly sound except in 2008, when its operations were not spared by 
the  global  financial  crisis.  That  year  was  very  difficult  for  CHNG,  as  the  costs  of  coal  and 
materials sharply increased but the Government kept power tariffs unchanged. As a result, the 
company  sustained  a  net  loss  of  CNY6.78  billion  (4.5%  of  sales),  and  net  cash  flow  from 
operating activities decreased by 74% compared with the previous year. From 2005 to 2007, its 
sales  increased  by  52%,  and  net  income  after  tax  increased  by  522%.  Yearly  net  operating 
income was around 10% of sales, while net income after tax was about 9% in 2007. 
 
14. 
CHNG's  financial  position  was  also  fairly  sound,  with  shareholders'  equity  comprising 
over 40% of its capital structure. However, it is observed that the company has large amounts of 
short-term debt maintained over the years. If the short-term debts were to be considered in the 
determination of its capital structure, the equity position would be about 33% in 2005, dropping 
to 28% in 2008. High short-term debt adversely affected the current ratio, which was less than 
1.0,  with  current  liabilities  exceeding  current  assets.  The  debt-service  coverage  ratio  (DSCR) 
was also below 1.0 because of payment on short maturities, which account for 45% of total debt.

20. 
Huaneng  Tianjin  IGCC  Co.  Ltd.  Financial  projections for HTICL are essentially based 
on the impact of the Project on the company's financial statements. The Project is assessed to 
be financially viable. The financial operations of the project company were projected for 2011–
2020  based  on  the  major  assumptions  described  below.  The  capital  investment  program 
considers  only  the  ADB-funded  project.  Annual  investment  outlays  were  adjusted  using  the 
projected annual escalation factors used in ADB projects. The projections use an exchange rate 
of  CNY6.83  to  $1.00.  After  project  completion,  no  major  capital  expenditures  are  expected 
throughout the project life. The expected economic life of the Project is 25 years,  with residual 
value assumed for the civil works and land-use right. 
 
21. 
Under  the  proposed  loan,  HTICL  will  be  required  to  maintain  a  DSCR  of  at  least  1.2 
times, rising to 1.3 times by 2016; a return on net fixed assets of not less than 6.0% from 2015 
onwards; accounts receivable not exceeding the equivalent of 3 months of sales; and a debt–
equity  ratio at  a  maximum  of  80:20  until  2015 and  70:30  thereafter.  To  ensure  that  this set  of 
financial  covenants  is  translated  into  appropriate  financial  policies  and  measures,  HTICL  will 
provide ADB each year with its rolling 10-year financial projections, showing how it proposes to 
meet  the  covenanted  targets.  The  financial  covenants  of  ADB  are  expected  to  be  satisfied 
during  the  life  of  the  Project.  The  DSCR  is  forecasted  to  be  adequate  throughout.  The  debt–
equity  ratio  will  be  within  the  prescribed  maximum  limit.  Other  financial  ratios  are  expected  to 
remain satisfactory.

Operating, Maintenance, and Other Expenses 

23. 
Consumption  of  standard  coal  is  275  kilograms  per  megawatt-hour  (MWh),  bringing 
annual coal consumption to around 400,000 ton (t). The coal price is estimated to be CNY575/t, 
including  13%  value-added  tax  (VAT).  Operating  and  other  local  expenses  are  adjusted  for 
inflation.  An  estimated  300  workers  will  be  required  to  run  the  Project  at  an  average  annual

salary. 
 
24. 
Other cost assumptions considered in the feasibility study include the cost of materials 
calculated  at  a  rate  of  CNY13/MWh  and  the  cost  of  other  items  including  administrative 
expenses  estimated  at  a  rate  of  CNY12/MWh.  Insurance  is  estimated  at  0.25%  each  year  on 
the original value of civil works and equipment. Categories of fixed assets are depreciated using 
the  straight  line  depreciation  method  at  different  annual  depreciation  rates  in  accordance  with 
the PRC’s guidelines, i.e., 2% for land-use rights, 3.3% for civil works, 5% for equipment, and 
20% for amortization of other intangible assets. A fund for equipment overhaul is withheld each 
year at 3.3% on the capital cost of equipment.

terms.  Interest  on  the  ADB  loan  is  calculated  based  on  the  current  London  inter-bank  offered

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 

A. 

Estimation of Costs 

Estimation of Benefits 

Economic Assumptions 
 
1. 
The  economic  analysis  of  the  Tianjin  Integrated  Gasification  Combined  Cycle  Power 
Plant  Project  was  carried  out  in  line  with  a  standard  cost–benefit  analysis  framework  and  in 
accordance  with  Asian  Development  Bank  Guidelines  for  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects. 1 
Economic  costs  and  benefit  are  at  2009  constant  prices  and  expressed  in  domestic  currency. 
The analysis was carried out over 25 years, in line with the project life assumed in the feasibility 
study approved by the National Development and Reform Commission. 
 
B. 
 
Tradable  commodities  were  valued  at  border  prices  at  the  prevailing  exchange  rate. 
2. 
Non-tradable  commodities  were  valued  through  shadow  prices  using  a  standard  conversion 
factor of 0.987, and the following specific conversion factors: 1.0 for equipment, 1.0 for skilled 
labor,  and  0.67  for  unskilled  labor.  Capital  costs  were  adjusted  to  eliminate  price  inflation, 
interest during construction, and taxes. 
 
C. 
 
The  main  economic  benefit  of  the  Project  is  from  power  generation  to  meet  electricity 
3. 
demand  from  end  users.  Expected  consistent  demand  growth  for  electricity  in  Tianjin  and  the 
North  China  Power  Grid,  to  which  the  Project  will  be  connected,  means  the  Project  will  meet 
new  demand  rather  than  substitute  for  power  from  any  existing  generation  capacity.  Analysis 
used  conservative  estimates  of  the  actual  benefits.  Lower  forecast  for  generation,  and 
conservative  in-plant  use  and  marginal  transmission  and  distribution  loss  of  15.21%  of 
generated  electricity,  formed  the  basis  for  incremental  net  energy  supply  of  1,245  gigawatt-
hours  per  year  to  end  users.  This  represents  a  56%  load  factor,  or  an  average  load  of  142.1 
megawatts.  
 
Economic  benefit  was  calculated  using  a  semilog 2  electricity  demand  function. 
4. 
Incremental benefits were quantified based on end users' willingness to pay (WTP). Consumer 
surplus—the difference between what one is willing to pay for a commodity and the amount one 
is  actually  required  to  pay—was  estimated  at  CNY0.752  per  kilowatt-hour  (kWh)  using  a 
semilog function.  
 
There  are  positive  environmental  benefits  from  avoided  pollution—annual  emissions  of 
5. 
43  tons  (t)  of  particulate  matters,  1,237  t  of  sulfur  dioxide,  3,325  t  of  nitrogen  oxide—from  a 
traditional  coal-fired  thermal  power  plant  as  the  alternative  energy  source.  Among  these 
environmental  benefits, the  most  prominent  ones  are  (i)  improved  human  health  from  avoided 
morbidity  and  mortality  from  fine  particulates,  (ii)  improved  human  welfare  from  improved 
visibility and reduced damage to materials from avoided air pollution, and (iii) positive impacts 
on environmental resources from avoided emission of carbon dioxide. For the evaluation of the 
environmental benefit to human health and welfare, the "benefit transfer method" suggested in 
ADB’s  Economic  Evaluation  of  Environmental  Impacts:  A  Workbook 3  is  used  for  this 
assessment,  and  these  benefits  were  included  in  the  estimation.  However,  complete 
quantification  and  estimation  of  all benefits  from  the  Project  were  not possible  for  lack  of  time 
and resources, among other reasons. The total benefits in this analysis can thus be interpreted 
as conservative estimates.

9. 
To  complement  the  deterministic  analysis  above,  risk  analysis  was  performed  using  a 
probabilistic  approach  to  the  perceived  risk  factors  that  affect  the  viability  of  the  Project.  The 
selected  risk  variables  included  capital  cost,  energy  sales,  operating  cost,  foreign  exchange 
rate, and WTP. Three thousand simulations were made. Based on the weighted average of all 
simulated combinations, the expected EIRR of the Project is 15.58% with a standard deviation 
of 2.10%. This is only 0.90 percentage points lower than the base value.  
 
F. 
 
10.  
The economic analysis confirms that the Project is sustainable. It was estimated that the 
Project has a net present economic value of CNY795.92 million. This quantification is based on 
a WTP tariff of CNY0.752/kWh and an energy use of 1,245 gigawatt-hours by end users. The 
analysis yields a base case EIRR of 16.49%. Sensitivity and risk analyses show that the EIRR is 
robust.

A. 

Introduction  

1. 
The  proposed  Tianjin  Integrated  Gasification  Combined  Cycle  Power  Plant  Project 
promotes  a  new  technology  being  developed  and  trialed  in  the  People's  Republic  of  China 
(PRC)  for  the  first  time.  Consequently,  following  environmental  impact  assessment  (EIA) 
approval  by  State  Environmental  Protection  Administration  in  July  2007,  it  has  undergone 
additional  rigorous  scrutiny  from  the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  which 
approved  the  Project's  feasibility  report  only  in  May  2009.  However,  the  approved  feasibility 
report is based on the same parameters of the Project upon which the EIA report was prepared. 
This appendix provides the status of the project implementation and evaluates its environmental 
compliance with the environmental management plan included in the EIA report. 

B. 

Background  

2. 
The  Project  consists  of  developing  a  250  megawatt  (MW)  integrated  gasification 
combined  cycle  (IGCC)  power  plant  and  a  research  center  to  further  research  polygeneration 
options, especially to pilot test hydrogen production and fuel cell power generation. The project 
is  located  in  Tianjin  Harbor  Industrial  Park  in  Tanggu  district  of  Tianjin.  The  scope  of 
construction work includes 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 
 
(iv) 

(v) 

(vi) 

(vii) 

a coal gasifier with a processing capacity of 2,000 tons per day (The coal gasifier 
used is a two-stage dry pulverized coal gasifier. The production process includes 
coal  grinding  and  drying,  pulverized  coal  compression  and  feeding,  coal 
gasification,  slag  removal,  dust  removal,  wet  scrubbing,  ash-flushing  water 
treatment, and wastewater treatment); 
gas  turbine  and  steam  turbine  combined  cycle,  consisting  of  one  171  MW  gas 
turbine, one 110 MW steam turbine, and a waste heat boiler; 
a  synthesis  gas  (syngas)  purification  system,  with  a  processing  capacity  of 
160,739 newton cubic meter per hour (Nm3/h); 
a sulfur recovery system (The Shell-Paques biological desulfurization process is 
used  to  remove  hydrogen  sulfide  in  the  raw  gas;  its  sulfur  recovery  capacity  is 
8.27 tons per day); 
a flaring system (In case of operation failure, syngas can be flared; the torch is 
80 meters high and 900 millimeters in diameter); 
other  items  including  an  air-separation  facility  with  a  capacity  of  43,497  cubic 
meters  per  hour,  water  supply,  power  supply,  an  ash-removal  system,  a 
wastewater-treatment and -discharge system, a water recycling system, a boiler 
water supply system, and a fire water system; 
a  storage  and  transport  system,  including  coal  transport,  a  storage  and

yard, an oil tank, and an oil pump room; 
temporary workers’ accommodation; and 
a permanent office and residential building.

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The Tianjin Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle Power Plant Project is a 250 megawatt power plant to provide base-load 
electric  power  generation  to  the  local  power  grid.  The  Project  will  generate  substantial  positive  environmental  benefits  by 
reducing  air  pollution  and  emissions  of  greenhouse  gases  such  as  carbon  dioxide  (CO2)  when  compared  with  replacement 
conventional coal-fired power plants. The Project will have local, regional, and global benefits from avoided particulate matter, 
sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxide, CO2, and other air pollutants. The Project supports the People's Republic of China (PRC) 
11th  Five-Year  Plan  (FYP)  2006–2010,  which  emphasizes  resource  conservation  and  environmental  protection  and  gives 
priority to improving energy efficiency and developing cleaner energy sources. The Project will support 11th FYP targets for (i) 
reducing SO2 emissions by 10% by reducing coal consumption for power generation and (ii) improving energy efficiency by 
20%  through  highly  efficient,  cutting-edge  technology.  The  Project  supports  the  goals  of  improving  energy  efficiency  and 
resource  utilization  outlined  in  the  China  Medium-  and  Long-Term  Energy  Conservation  Plan  2005  and  the  Decision  of  the 
State  Council  on  Enhancing  Energy  Conservation  (2006)  No.  28,  which  emphasizes  energy  conservation,  particularly  in 
power  generation.  The  proposed  Project  is  consistent  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  Medium-Term  Strategy  II  2006–
2008  strategic  priority  of  managing  the  environment,  as  well  as  the  country  strategy  and  program  for  the  PRC  strategic 
development objective of improving the environment.  

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
 
The Project intervenes to reduce poverty in an indirect manner by conserving energy and reducing emissions in the region.  
 
2. Design Features.  
There is no pro-poor design in the Project.  

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
A large power generation company, the Huaneng Tianjin IIGCC Co. Ltd (HTICL), is the primary beneficiary of the Project. The 
secondary  beneficiaries  are  factories  in  the  industrial  park.  The  tertiary  beneficiaries  are  people  in  the  industrial  park.  No 
potential  needs  and  constraints  are  found  among  stakeholders  in  terms  of  social  development  or  in  accessing  the  benefits 
and services of the Project. 

B.  Consultation and Participation 

1.  Provide a summary of the consultation and participation process during the project preparation.

Appendix 16 

INNOVATIVE PROJECT PROCESSING AND PROJECT READINESS FILTERS 

Introduction 

Innovative Project Processing Approach   

 
A. 
 
1. 
The  preparation  of  the  Tianjin  Integrated  Gasification  Combined  Cycle  Power  Plant 
Project has been very different from that of other traditional loans on account of its late formal 
inclusion in the country assistance plan in 2009. It is a rare, if not the first, loan project without 
formal  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA)  in  the  People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC). 
The project team has adopted an innovative approach for tracking internal approvals in the PRC 
and  its  inclusion  in  the  country  program,  as  well  as  to  address  key  issues  in  processing,  as 
detailed below.  
 
B. 
 
2. 
Project Preparatory Technical Assistance. Project preparatory TA accompanies loan 
inclusion in the country assistance pipeline. Small-scale TA for $200,000 was approved in 2008 
to illustrate the strong interest of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in integrated gasification 
combined  cycle  technology  and  provide  urgent  processing  momentum.  This  resulted  in 
satisfactory  preparation  such  that,  soon  after  the  Project's  inclusion  in  the  program,  loan  fact-
finding was completed in May 2009.   
 
Advanced  Contracting.  The  Project  was  expected  to  have  fast-track  implementation 
3. 
upon feasibility report approval, the timing of which was unclear due to the demonstration nature 
of the Project. In view of delays in its inclusion in the country program and uncertainties about 
the  timing  of  approval  of  the  feasibility  report,  ADB  management  approved  the  advanced 
contracting  in  August  2008  to  allow  procurement  to  follow  ADB's  procurement  guidelines  and 
thus be eligible for ADB financing when the Project gets included in the pipeline.  
 
4. 
Onlending  Issues.  The  Project  is  implemented  by  a  state-owned  enterprise  (SOE) 
without provincial government support. The ADB loan to a SOE without provincial government 
onlending created a big challenge as the Ministry of Finance is reluctant to onlend directly to an 
SOE without very strict counter guarantees. The introduction of the Export-Import Bank of China 
(EXIM  Bank),  a  policy  bank  of  the  Government  with  expertise  in  similar  onlending  operations, 
has resolved this issue.  
 
C.
